items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 1am and 4am tomorrow, Saturday 5th February. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.84mAODN at 2:15am tomorrow, Saturday 5th February, which is 0.58m above tide tables, Wind Force 6, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Saturday 5th February.

items.description: North Sea coast at Hornsea

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: This flood warning has been issued due to overtopping waves and spray expected as a result of high tides and strong winds.  Consequently, flooding of property and roads and farmland is expected on the high tides between 18:15 and 20:30 this evening, Friday 04/02/2022. Areas most at risk are properties from Marine Drive, along South Promenade, Hornsea Burton Road and along Stream Dike and Foss Beck. Coastal conditions are expected to improve on subsequent tides but may trigger further alerts over the next few days due to strong winds.  Please put your flood plan into action and be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast and will update this message in 12 hours or as required with updated information.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton

We expect high tide levels at the harbourside in Southwold. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.79mAODN at 11:45pm today, Friday 4th February, which is 0.61m above tide tables, wind Force 6, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Saturday 5th February.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

We continue to monitor the situation closely and our incident staff are ready to respond if necessary.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is possible over the next few days until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This Flood Alert will remain in force for the next few days due to sustained high water levels caused by the natural tide locking effect in the Broads. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth is restricting the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. Also, overtopping of the railway embankment at Haddiscoe New Cut has caused a reduction in the flood alert threshold. The Environment Agency and Network Rail are currently on site and working to resolve the issue. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Saturday 5th February.

items.description: Northumberland coast
items.message:
This flood alert has been removed. The risk of flooding from wind, waves and high tides at Beadnell and Newbiggin Bay has now reduced. No further overtopping and spray is expected. We continue to monitor the situation and if necessary we will issue the alert for the high tide tomorrow evening, 05/02/2022.
For a 5 day flood risk forecast please see the GOV.UK website or for a weather forecast see the Met Office website.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely today between 7pm and midnight, Friday 4th February. We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches, and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.73 mAODN at 8:45pm today, Friday 4th February, which is 0.52m above tide tables, wind Force 6, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Saturday 5th February.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 1am and 4am tomorrow, Saturday 5th February. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in the surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.54mAODN at 2:15am tomorrow, Saturday 5th February, which is 0.50m above tide tables, Wind Force 6, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.79mAODN at 11:45pm today, Friday 4th February, which is 0.61m above tide tables, Wind Force 6, Westerly. floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 1am and 4am tomorrow, Saturday 5th February. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded.  Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.54mAODN at 2:15am tomorrow, Saturday 5th February, which is 0.50m above tide tables, Wind Force 6, Westerly. items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is possible over the next few days. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth is currently restricting the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Saturday 5th February.

items.description: Coast from Ramsgate to Kingsdown
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This flood alert has been issued as a result of the high tide expected to affect coastal and tidal locations tomorrow, 5 February 2022. Tides will be at their highest between 01:15am and 01:45am tomorrow early morning, 5 February 2022. Flooding is expected at these times to affect lower lying locations nearest the coast throughout this area, between Ramsgate and Kingsdown, however conditions may apply two hours either side of the high tide. Coastal conditions should ease for the 5 February 2022 on the next high tide at 02:00pm.  

Please be careful in areas around the coast during this period of concern and avoid contact with flood waters present. We are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. For those that use it, the total water level is forecast to be 3.65m AOD at Dover at 01:30am tomorrow, 5 February 2022. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning 5 February 2022, or as the situation changes.

The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Cromer of 3.10 mAODN at 8:30pm today, Friday 4th February, which is 0.69m above tide tables, wind Force 6, Westerly. items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.65 mAOD at 05:15 on 05/02/2022.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 35 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next 3 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 05/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely today between 7pm and midnight, Friday 4th February. We may see water on Beach Road at Cley, and Beach Road at Salthouse. Footpaths in the marshes may also become inaccessible. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.73 mAODN at 8:45pm today, Friday 4th February, which is 0.52m above tide tables, wind Force 6, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Saturday 5th February.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message:
Large and powerful waves are expected to overtop sea defences as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. Tides will be at their highest between 20:00 and 21:00 today, 04/02/22. Flooding to the promenade/seafront is expected/possible at these times. However, conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. We expect flooding to affect Hunstanton seafront. 
The local Authority are closing the flood gates at Hunstanton which will make access difficult. 
Detailed tidal information for those who use it: the predicted astronomical tide level is 3.90 mAODN. The forecast surge height is 0.27 m. The forecast tide level is 4.57 mAOD. The forecast wind direction is W with a strength Force 6.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous and stay away from large waves as they are dangerous.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 05/02/22, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is expected at these times to affect lower lying locations nearest the coast throughout this area, between St Margret’s at Cliffe to Sandgate, however conditions may apply two hours either side of the high tide. Coastal conditions should ease for the 5 February 2022 on the next high tide at 02:00pm.  

Please be careful in areas around the coast during this period of concern and avoid contact with flood waters present. We are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely on Friday the 04/02/2022, between 12:30 PM and 02:30 PM. The areas most at risk are around Storth Sandside. Impacts are also possible at Canal Foot, and low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale. The high tide on Saturday afternoon is expected to be higher and may result in us issuing a further alert. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 02:06 PM on 05/02/2022. High tides today, 04/02/2022, are not expected to reach the Flood Alert level. Areas most at risk include Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stannah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected between 12:06 PM and 04:06 PM on 05/02/2022. After this tide‚ the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 05/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming high tides. 
Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads at Fiddlers Ferry between 02:00 PM and 02:30 PM, Eastford Road between 02:15 PM and 02:45 PM and Arpley Bridge between 02:30 PM and 03:00 PM on 04/02/2022. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. 
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2 days and as a result we may issue further alerts. 
The high tide on Friday evening 04/02/2022 is not expected to reach flood alert. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 05/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from St Bees Head to Millom
items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is possible on Friday the 04/02/2022, between 12:30 PM and 02:30 PM. Areas most at risk include Low lying areas along the coast from St Bees Head to Millom including Ravenglass and Annaside. The high tide on Saturday afternoon is expected to be higher and may result in us issuing a further alert. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
